text: so to continue the discussion <@U2UD2AH98> … orderer in v1.0 is the consentor in 0.6
it may be best for you to try 0.6 in  <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/fabric,branches>
<@U0ULK2JPP> it works with 0.6. Thank you very much for your help!
<@U2UD2AH98> thank you for checking it out… I still need to look at the peerchaincodedev mode in master… will do that later and update
btw, how did you know that I was using the main branch?

<@U0Y55KNG2|kletkeman> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/kletkeman/F2UEV1SKV/pasted_image_at_2016_10_26_11_51_am.png|Pasted image at 2016-10-26, 11:51 AM> and commented: We are running long term load tests on a Bluemix peer and have found that, on a busy chain, it is essentially impossible to get the same chain height on all four peers at the same time. I have tried dozens of times and the closest I have come is to see the application contact point (vp0) be only 1 block behind ... but that never lasts ... the furthest I've seen is around 20 blocks behind ... there is a lot of hysteresis in that so it acts like a bungee cord. What this meant for my Hyperledger Divergence Monitor was that it could never rely on the chain heights in order to determine divergence. I updated the latest to handle this by calculating the min height and using that for convergence. That way, it will lag a few minutes behind the maximum chain height, but will give the best guess possible at the time as to whether the chain has diverged. See the screen shot for how this actually looks, and try it out here: <https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/blockchain-samples/tree/master/testing/node-red/Hyperledger%20Hash%20Divergence%20Monitor>

initial_comment.comment: We are running long term load tests on a Bluemix peer and have found that, on a busy chain, it is essentially impossible to get the same chain height on all four peers at the same time. I have tried dozens of times and the closest I have come is to see the application contact point (vp0) be only 1 block behind ... but that never lasts ... the furthest I've seen is around 20 blocks behind ... there is a lot of hysteresis in that so it acts like a bungee cord. What this meant for my Hyperledger Divergence Monitor was that it could never rely on the chain heights in order to determine divergence. I updated the latest to handle this by calculating the min height and using that for convergence. That way, it will lag a few minutes behind the maximum chain height, but will give the best guess possible at the time as to whether the chain has diverged. See the screen shot for how this actually looks, and try it out here: <https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/blockchain-samples/tree/master/testing/node-red/Hyperledger%20Hash%20Divergence%20Monitor>

text: Oops ... just noticed that there is a minor display error on the header ... but you get the idea

<@U2UD2AH98> recommend you continue using 0.6  …but for completeness with the original issue on master - you’d need to add  `CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev` to the deploy command to run in dev mode so something like `CORE_PEER_COMMITTER_LEDGER_ORDERER=0.0.0.0:5151 CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args":["init","a","100","b","200"]}’`
